doc.after: The king vulture is one of the most common species of birds represented in the Mayan codices.[54] Its glyph is easily distinguishable by the knob on the birdâs beak and by the concentric circles that make up the birdâs eyes.[54] Sometimes the bird is portrayed as a god with a human body and a bird head.[54] According to Mayan mythology, this god often carried messages between humans and the other gods.[46] It is also used to represent Cozcacuauhtli, the thirteenth day of the month in the Mayan calendar (13 Reed).[54] An ocellated turkey (Meleagris ocellata) was also considered to be the bird depicted, but the hooked bill and wattle point to the raptor.[11]
